By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
A racial controversy is brewing
here over the refusal of a local
barber to give a haircut to a
Negro who is a Hopkins student.
Wednesday night a number of
Hopkins students met and decided to boycott and picket the
Marylander barber shop at 3501
St. Paul Street, if a delegation
of students failed to gain concessions from the manager of the
shop, Victor De Ruggiero.

KENNETH BROWN

Tuition Increase
Set For Fall '67
The Hopkins administration
has announced that tuition fees
throughout the University will be
raised from its present $1,800 to
$2,000 effective July 1, 1967.
In disclosing the announcement, Ross Jones, Secretary to
the University, stated that "the
annual cost of operating the
University has risen more than
$20 Million since 1961 and expenditures are more than $4 million higher than they were when
the last tuition increase was announced in 1964."

The conflict developed about
two weeks ago when Hopkins
freshman Ken Brown, a Negro,
went to the shop for a haircut. He was refused service on
the grounds that he was a Hopkins student and that Hopkins
students were not served there.
The incident aroused the suspicion of other Hopkins freshmen.
Test Shop
To test the barbers explanation, Stephen Shriver, another
Hopkins student, went to the
barber shop wearing a Hopkins
jacket. Shriver was given a haircut.

Retired Air Force Brigadier
General Benjamin G. Willis, Assistant to the President and Director of Planning at the University of Delaware, has been appointed Coordinator of Sponsored Research Administration at
the University.
Dr. Bruce Partridge, Hopkins
Vice President for Administration, in making the announcement, stated that Willis' duties
will include directing the fiscal
administration of federally sponsored research programs, including financial reporting and negotiations with the federal government.

White House Staff Member
General Willis served on the
White House staff from 1955-58
as Air Force advisor to Harold
E. Stassen, Special Assistant to
The President for Disarmament.
The General served as Commander of the Iceland Defense Force
(NATO) from 1959-1961, followed
by a two year tour of duty as
Commander of the First Air
Force Region, Stewart Air Force
Base.
General Willis was educated at
Norwich University and the University of Maryland. As a bomber
squadron commander in the
European theater during World
War II, General Willis flew 63
combat missions.

Citing the need for immediate
action, Drake and Shriver asked
for suggestions from the floor.
Boycott Shop
Suggestions were, picketing a
boycott of the shop, legal action,
calls for the support of Mayor
McKeklin and Governor-Elect
Agnew, and a delegation to approach the manager of the shop.
By a near-unaminous vote the
group decided to send a delegation of four students to the shop
on Thursdayi November 10 to
discuss the situation wit h
De Ruggiero. If that proved
fruitless, picketing would begin
today outside the Marylander
Apartments, where the barber
shop is located.
Plans to end discrimination in
other Baltimore barber shops and
in housing and accommodation
were discussed, but the meeting
was adjourned before any definite plans were made.
The students hope that a boycott of the Marylander Barber
shop may put pressure on other
shops in North Baltimore to end
discrimination.

Admits Nine
The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
Phi Beta Kappa selected nine
members of the Class of 1967
this fall.
Acceptances were based on
class rank for six semesters of
college work. The remainder of
this year's selections will be made
in the spring.
The nine students selected include John Barnhardt, Sanford
Cohn, Lewis Cylus, Richard Elinson, Michael Gross, Charles Jaffee, Joel Sirkin, Chesleigh Snow,.
and Stephen Targin.
Dr. George Boas, Professor
Emeritus,in History of Philosophy, spoke in honor of the new
members at the formal initiation
ceremony held October 27.

•

First Fall Selection
This year marks the first time
in the history of the Hopkins
chapter that students have been
selected before the spring of their
senior year. Professor Stephen
Wolff, Secretary of the chapter.
cited the importance of this
change in policy. "In the past,"
he stated, "the election was held
during the spring and two weeks
later the students were gone."
"The presence of seniors in the
organization during the school
year will provide a greater sense
of continuity," Wolff continued:
The policies of the Hopkins
chapter are now more in line
with other universities around
the country. Most other institutions also select the top two-tothree percent of the class in tilt+
fall of the senior year.

Alumni Trustee Appointed

"The Mew Morality—Situation Ethics"

The Johns Hopkins University
Board of Trustees has elected
Jacob L. Hain, chairman of Bush
Terminal Company, Brooklyn,
New York, as an Alumni Trustee.

Rev. Mr. James Hannegan, S.J.

Mr. Hain's election for a sixyear term of office on the Board
is the continuation of a plan
established several years ago
whereby the Board elects an
alumnus of the University each
year to participate more closely
in University affairs.
A 1923 Hopkins graduate, Mr.
Hain succeeds Dr. J. H. Fitzgerald Dunning, whose term of service expired in October 1966.

With regard to the purpose and management of
the Hopkins bookstore, plant manager Wesley Taylor
recently remarked: "I like the concept of operating
without a loss to the University."
Because Mr. Taylor measures the degree of University well-being solely in terms of dollars and cents,
he is unfortunately unaware that the University is indeed
suffering a much greater loss from the standpoint of
its role as an educational and cultural enterprise.
Noted historians Henry Steele Commager and Eric
Goldman, in addresses to the National Association of
College Stores last April, made some profound observalions as to the role of the bookstore on the modern university campus.
"The changes that have come in the Bookstores,"
Cornmager states, "have been for the most part quantitative rather than qualitative.
"You (the bookstore managers) have not... adjusted yourselves to that fundamental change, the change
in the relationship of the university to the enterprise of
learning which is called for. You have not yet, I think,
accepted an academic role as the integral part of your
own character and your own enterprise."
Commager goes on to relate this new role to that
of the university, and he concludes that the university
itself must take the responsibility to further the academic
function of the bookstore."The university has an interest
in getting books into the hands of students, inculcating
in all who are connected with it the habits of buying
books, in lifting the level of community -literacy. It does
not have a legitimate interest in selling toothpaste or
undershirts. These are laudible enterprises, but the Bookstore is not responsible for serving this particular convenience."
Consequently, says Commager, the bookstore "no
longer should be expected to show a profit than a university theatre of music department should be expected
to show a profit."
Goldman takes a wider, though no less compelling
viewpoint, when he relates the role of the Bookstore to
file intellectually oriented members of the post-urban society which he calls Metroamerica. "In the new role of
the university—with its special relationship to the culturally important Metroamerican group—why should not
die Campus Store be considered another and significant
department of the university?
"Nobody asks whether or not the department of
history or the department of zoology is a financial asset.
'Why should there not be the same attitude toward the
store which is the surest link to the continuing and
mounting needs of an adult public?
"Some day in some specific place, someone is going
to propose a College Store as a genuine cultural center.
I venture the opinion that you may be surprised at the
reaction. There are fresh winds stirring inside universities and outside them—and it is not at all inconceivable
to me that such a plan would win the approval of the
more advanced university administrators and even attract substantial endowment funds from Metroamericans."
These observations have special validity for the
Hopkins campus. With the imminent completion of a
new bookstore, the University can insure its maximum
academic potential is realized by reversing its current
policy of operating to make a profit. That the profit
from the bookstore goes to make up deficits elsewhere
In the budget only shows that students are being exploited, when in fact they should be given every consideration, in the purchase of essentials such as books.
Furthermore, in view of the expansion of campus
facilities over the next twenty-five years, Hopkins will
come to serve more and more of the intellectual community. The bookstore can and should be a primary
means of fulfilling this responsibility,but can be so only if
the administration is willing to reconsider its current
policy and take a more progressive attitude towards the
role of the bookstore.

By GERALD I. BRECHER
As far as can be seen from the
results of Tuesday's election, the
Republicans are not yet dead.
Dwight Eisenhower at the Republican convention in 1964
made a crack about 'sensation
seeking columnists and commentators' which sparked the loudest
cheers for anything anyone said
all that convention. In 1966, the
electorate seem to be pushing
those same columnists and commentators further out into the
cold by sweeping the G.O.P. back
into its strongest position since
1958.
Read Journals
If one read the journals and
newspapers in 1964, following the
election, one was told by just
about every writer in the country
that the Republicans were on
their way to become extinct as
the dodo; that they would soon
be on their way to joining the
Whigs and Federalists in the
graveyard of American politics.
Well, it's only two years later
now, and obviously nothing of
the sort has happened.
The fact that with him Goldwater dragged down most other
Republicans ought not to have
been construed as an inherent
weakness in the party. Rather
one might call it a reverse coattail effect, good money being
ruined by bad. But Goldwater is
not the Republican party, or at
least one would hope not. More
likely Richard Nixon is.
If the commentators had been
sharp in '64 they could have seen
knew
this.
that
Everyone
Lyndon Johnson is not loveable.
It's unlikely that any great wave
of public affection will sweep the
land, and unless Lyndon manages to end the war in Vietnam
before 1968, it's not so risky to
predict that with 'Lyndon Johnson's War' wrapped around their
throats, that the Democrats may
well come to fm-ther grief in
those elections.
Goldwater Nothing
The fact that Goldwater was
such a nothing doesn't make it
that Lyndon Johnson is then a
great folk hero. It would seem
that as many congressmen owe
their defeat this year to Johnson as owed their victories, not
to him in 1964, but to his being
opposed by Goldwater. Rather
than loving Lyndon, the people
fear him; and fearing him, they
reject his congressmen and senators and governors.
It's a two edged sword though.
In rejecting Lyndon and his
friends, the voters did themselves
no mat favors in a lot of places.
If the Republicans didn't ruin

themselves in '64, they may yet
have done it in '66 with the election of that bad actor turnedworse politician, Ronald Reagan
in California.
Public relations candidates
seem to be a newfound strength
for the Republicans. Lindsay in
New York is nothing if not the
figment of some p.r. man's imagination. It's as if he stepped out
of a Doyle Dane ad onto the
political scene. Perhaps he does
try harder, who knows. But if
he doesnt Nixon surely does.
The old Nixon is dead and
buried. No more Checker, no
more tales of how poor he was,
of how he slaved through college
and all that jazz. Oh no, not for
Tricky Dicky. He's now the big
corporation lawyer; big apartment on Fifth Avenue and all,
daughters coming out at all the
worst dances in New York, Tr pier suits; the works. Mr. Responsible. The New Mr. Republican. Yecch, it's still the smear
artist from California, the slick
as greased pig mudslinger, red
baiter and know-nothing. And
him and that dough faced, mealy
mouthed no account hoofer Reagan are going to save the country. From what?

Well, this is from what: with
the help of Percy, the boy won(ter, they'll beat all the grand
old men like Douglas, and start
getting this country running
sensibly again. No more of this
academic freedom jazz (Berkely,
a la Reagan — Rutgers, a la
Nixon); no more of these pushy
minority niggers (communists,
Jews, P.R.'s, women, children,
etc.) a return to the grand old
days of law and order (BY
GOD!) will be what's happening;
Prayers back in the schools,
where they belong; no more
crime, no more inflation, no more
Great Societies, New Deals, New
Frontiers, Eras of God Feelings
or anything like that. No sir,
Nixon and Reagan, and maybe
George Wallace — stand up for
AMERICA. By God, if you don't
sir . .
Well, anyway, the Republicans
aren't dead, not by a long shot;
hell, how could they be. There
are still millions of just plain
folks all over this country, just
waiting to get them slickers out
of the White House, out of the
capitol, maybe even out of the
country. The Republicans are in
no danger of dying; there's too

"M"IS FOR THE MANY THINGS
YOU'LL TEACH HER
Nobody will dispute—surely not I—that raising children
Is a task which requires full time and awesome skills.
Nonetheless, a recent nationwide survey has revealed a
startling fact: mothers who go back to work after their
children are safely through the early years are notably
happier, better adjusted, and more fulfilled than mothers
who simply remain housewives. Moreover—and mark this
well—the children of such working mothers are themselves
happier, better adjusted, and more fulfilled!
All very well, you say, but what's it got to do with you?
Isn't it obvious? If you are underachieving at college, get
your mother a job.
What kind of job? Well sir, your mother is probably
between 35 and 50 years of age, so certain occupations
must immediately be ruled out. Logging,for example. Or
whaling. Or carhopping.
But don't despair. There are other kinds of jobs—not
many, to be sure, but some. However, you must not stick
Mom in just any old job. You must remember that after
the excitement of raising you, she would be bored to tears
as a file clerk, for instance, or as a dolman.(A dolman, as
we all know, is someone who brings handfuls of water to
track layers. With the recent invention of the pail, dolmen
are gradually falling into technological unemployment.)
But I digress. I was saying, find Mom a job worthy of
her talents, something challenging that uses her vast wisdom and experience but, at the same time, is not too hard
on her obsolescing tissues. That's what Walter Sigafoos
did, and the results were brilliantly successful.
Walter, a sophomore at the Upper Maryland College of
Wickerwork and Belles Lettres, majoring in raffia, approached the problem scientifically. First he asked himself
what his mother did best. Well sir, what she did best was
to keep hollering,"Dress warm, Walter!"
At first glance this seemed a skill not widely in demand,
but Walter was not discouraged. He sent out hundreds of
inquiries and today, I am pleased to report, his mother is
happily employed as wardrobe mistress for the Montreal
Canadiens.
Another fortunate venture was that of Frank C. Gransmire, a junior at the Oregon State Conservatory of Music
and Optometry, majoring in sties. Frank,like Walter, did
a survey in depth of his mother's talents. Chief among
them, he found, was her ability to make a roast of beef
feed the whole family for three days. So, naturally, Frank
got her a job at the Museum of Natural History.
What has one to do with the other, you ask? Isn't It
obvious? Anyone who can stretch ribs like that belongs in
paleontology.

Fr sh Gridders Finish
By JIM SLOAN
The freshman football team
wound up its three game season
with a clean slate as it defeated
the Pennsylvania Military Col
lege frosh, 28-21, Friday, at Homewood.
P.M.C., sporting a strong passing threat and a stout defense,
were "upset" by our hustling and
aggressive frosh squad.
"Our competitive attitude and
hard hitting attack were big factors in the victory," beamed
Coach Bob Scott.
This year's contingent averaged
over thirty points per game, and
was the highest scoring frosh
team that Scott has coached in
13 years. The squad possessed an all-around attack. After
recovering from a midseason low
point against Western Maryland,
the Baby Jays' spirit and enthusiasm proved strong.
Defense Impressive
Led by an improved pass coverage and strong interior line,
the frosh defense turned out to
be a major stumbling block for
the PMC offense. Ends Bob
Billows,
Dick
and
Rohlfing
tackles Neal Vinson and Jim
Lotto, and center Bill Nersesian
consistently applied pressure on
the opponent's quarterback.
Meanwhile the secondary of
Dave Hooper, Ed McGinnis, and
John Hicks adequately covered
opponent's pass receivers. Steve
Clark was aggressive as defensive
tackle. Nevertheless PMC was
able to connect on several passes
to the flat. One of these ended
in a 66 yard run for their first
score.
The Scoring Trio
Russell Moore, Paul Weiss, and
Bob Rohlfing again sparked the
Hopkins offense. Quarterback
Moore was 8 for 18 through the
air, and connected for two touchdowns and one conversion. Weiss
gained 173 yards in 23 attempts
for an average of about eight
yards per carry. He sported two
TD's rushing and one on a pass
from Moore.
Rohlfing scored the fourth Jay
TD on a "freak" pass that
bounced off the intended receiver, Larry Roberts. Rohlfing
also gained two points for the
frosh when he tackled a PMC
halfback in the end zone for a
safety. John Hicks, filling in for
injured Dan Rosenfeld, gave a
fine performance in the fullback
slot, gaining about five yards per
carry.
Weiss came up with the first
score of the contest on a 36 yard
jaunt in the first quarter. PMC
quickly came back with its 66
yard pass play, but they were
later unable to stop the Frosh
Jays' attack. Weiss again scored,
this time on a one yard plunge,
then proceeded to score a twopoint conversion. The second
quarter saw Rohlfing spill PMC
for the safety, and Moore hit
Weiss on a 14 yard TD pass.
Neither team posted a score in
the third period, but in the final
quarter, Hopkins and PMC both
crossed the goal line. With 55
seconds remaining, Penn. Military scored again, and the contest ended 28-21.
Season Statistics
Weiss led the frosh gridmen
in the season's scoring-60 points
in three games. He gained 333

By DAVID SCHNEIDERMAN
A racial controversy is brewing
here over the refusal of a local
barber to give a haircut to a
Negro who is a Hopkins student.
Wednesday night a number of
Hopkins students met and decided to boycott and picket the
Marylander barber shop at 3501
St. Paul Street, if a delegation
of students failed to gain concessions from the manager of the
shop, Victor De Ruggiero.

KENNETH BROWN

Tuition Increase
Set For Fall '67
The Hopkins administration
has announced that tuition fees
throughout the University will be
raised from its present $1,800 to
$2,000 effective July 1, 1967.
In disclosing the announcement, Ross Jones, Secretary to
the University, stated that "the
annual cost of operating the
University has risen more than
$20 Million since 1961 and expenditures are more than $4 million higher than they were when
the last tuition increase was announced in 1964."

The conflict developed about
two weeks ago when Hopkins
freshman Ken Brown, a Negro,
went to the shop for a haircut. He was refused service on
the grounds that he was a Hopkins student and that Hopkins
students were not served there.
The incident aroused the suspicion of other Hopkins freshmen.
Test Shop

barber shop wearing a Hopkins
jacket. Shriver was given a haircut.

Citing the need for immediate

Boycott Shop
Suggestions were, picketing a
boycott of the shop, legal action,
calls for the support of Mayor
McKeklin and Governor-Elect
Agnew, and a delegation to approach the manager of the shop.
By a near-unaminous vote the
group decided to send a delegation of four students to the shop
on Thursdayi November 10 to
discuss the situation wit h
De Ruggiero. If that proved
fruitless, picketing would begin
today outside the Marylander
Apartments, where the barber
shop is located.
Plans to end discrimination in
other Baltimore barber shops and
in housing and accommodation
were discussed, but the meeting
was adjourned before any definite plans were made.
The students hope that a boycott of the Marylander Barber
shop may put pressure on other
shops in North Baltimore to end
discrimination.

Admits Nine
The Johns Hopkins Chapter of
Phi Beta Kappa selected nine
members of the Class of 1967
this fall.
Acceptances were based on
class rank for six semesters of
college work. The remainder of
this year's selections will be made
in the spring.
The nine students selected include John Barnhardt, Sanford
Cohn, Lewis Cylus, Richard Elinson, Michael Gross, Charles Jaffee, Joel Sirkin, Chesleigh Snow,.
and Stephen Targin.
Dr. George Boas, Professor
Emeritus,in History of Philosophy, spoke in honor of the new
members at the formal initiation
ceremony held October 27.

•

First Fall Selection
This year marks the first time
in the history of the Hopkins
chapter that students have been
selected before the spring of their
senior year. Professor Stephen
Wolff, Secretary of the chapter.
cited the importance of this
change in policy. "In the past,"
he stated, "the election was held
during the spring and two weeks
later the students were gone."
"The presence of seniors in the
organization during the school
year will provide a greater sense
of continuity," Wolff continued:
The policies of the Hopkins
chapter are now more in line
with other universities around
the country. Most other institutions also select the top two-tothree percent of the class in tilt+
fall of the senior year.

With regard to the purpose and management of
the Hopkins bookstore, plant manager Wesley Taylor
recently remarked: "I like the concept of operating
without a loss to the University."
Because Mr. Taylor measures the degree of University well-being solely in terms of dollars and cents,
he is unfortunately unaware that the University is indeed
suffering a much greater loss from the standpoint of
its role as an educational and cultural enterprise.
Noted historians Henry Steele Commager and Eric
Goldman, in addresses to the National Association of
College Stores last April, made some profound observalions as to the role of the bookstore on the modern university campus.
"The changes that have come in the Bookstores,"
Cornmager states, "have been for the most part quantitative rather than qualitative.
"You (the bookstore managers) have not... adjusted yourselves to that fundamental change, the change
in the relationship of the university to the enterprise of
learning which is called for. You have not yet, I think,
accepted an academic role as the integral part of your
own character and your own enterprise."
Commager goes on to relate this new role to that
of the university, and he concludes that the university
itself must take the responsibility to further the academic
function of the bookstore."The university has an interest
in getting books into the hands of students, inculcating
in all who are connected with it the habits of buying
books, in lifting the level of community -literacy. It does
not have a legitimate interest in selling toothpaste or
undershirts. These are laudible enterprises, but the Bookstore is not responsible for serving this particular convenience."
Consequently, says Commager, the bookstore "no
longer should be expected to show a profit than a university theatre of music department should be expected
to show a profit."
Goldman takes a wider, though no less compelling
viewpoint, when he relates the role of the Bookstore to
file intellectually oriented members of the post-urban society which he calls Metroamerica. "In the new role of
the university—with its special relationship to the culturally important Metroamerican group—why should not
die Campus Store be considered another and significant
department of the university?
"Nobody asks whether or not the department of
history or the department of zoology is a financial asset.
'Why should there not be the same attitude toward the
store which is the surest link to the continuing and
mounting needs of an adult public?
"Some day in some specific place, someone is going
to propose a College Store as a genuine cultural center.
I venture the opinion that you may be surprised at the
reaction. There are fresh winds stirring inside universities and outside them—and it is not at all inconceivable
to me that such a plan would win the approval of the
more advanced university administrators and even attract substantial endowment funds from Metroamericans."
These observations have special validity for the
Hopkins campus. With the imminent completion of a
new bookstore, the University can insure its maximum
academic potential is realized by reversing its current
policy of operating to make a profit. That the profit
from the bookstore goes to make up deficits elsewhere
In the budget only shows that students are being exploited, when in fact they should be given every consideration, in the purchase of essentials such as books.
Furthermore, in view of the expansion of campus
facilities over the next twenty-five years, Hopkins will
come to serve more and more of the intellectual community. The bookstore can and should be a primary
means of fulfilling this responsibility,but can be so only if
the administration is willing to reconsider its current
policy and take a more progressive attitude towards the
role of the bookstore.

Well, it's only two years later

"M"IS FOR THE MANY THINGS
YOU'LL TEACH HER
Nobody will dispute—surely not I—that raising children
Is a task which requires full time and awesome skills.
Nonetheless, a recent nationwide survey has revealed a
startling fact: mothers who go back to work after their
children are safely through the early years are notably
happier, better adjusted, and more fulfilled than mothers
who simply remain housewives. Moreover—and mark this
well—the children of such working mothers are themselves
happier, better adjusted, and more fulfilled!
All very well, you say, but what's it got to do with you?
Isn't it obvious? If you are underachieving at college, get
your mother a job.
What kind of job? Well sir, your mother is probably
between 35 and 50 years of age, so certain occupations
must immediately be ruled out. Logging,for example. Or
whaling. Or carhopping.
But don't despair. There are other kinds of jobs—not
many, to be sure, but some. However, you must not stick
Mom in just any old job. You must remember that after
the excitement of raising you, she would be bored to tears
as a file clerk, for instance, or as a dolman.(A dolman, as
we all know, is someone who brings handfuls of water to
track layers. With the recent invention of the pail, dolmen
are gradually falling into technological unemployment.)
But I digress. I was saying, find Mom a job worthy of
her talents, something challenging that uses her vast wisdom and experience but, at the same time, is not too hard
on her obsolescing tissues. That's what Walter Sigafoos
did, and the results were brilliantly successful.
Walter, a sophomore at the Upper Maryland College of
Wickerwork and Belles Lettres, majoring in raffia, approached the problem scientifically. First he asked himself
what his mother did best. Well sir, what she did best was
to keep hollering,"Dress warm, Walter!"
At first glance this seemed a skill not widely in demand,
but Walter was not discouraged. He sent out hundreds of
inquiries and today, I am pleased to report, his mother is
happily employed as wardrobe mistress for the Montreal
Canadiens.
Another fortunate venture was that of Frank C. Gransmire, a junior at the Oregon State Conservatory of Music
and Optometry, majoring in sties. Frank,like Walter, did
a survey in depth of his mother's talents. Chief among
them, he found, was her ability to make a roast of beef
feed the whole family for three days. So, naturally, Frank
got her a job at the Museum of Natural History.
What has one to do with the other, you ask? Isn't It
obvious? Anyone who can stretch ribs like that belongs in
paleontology.

HOMEWOOD. BALTIMORE. NOVEMBER 11. 1966

NEWS-LETTER

Fr sh Gridders Finish
By JIM SLOAN
The freshman football team
wound up its three game season
with a clean slate as it defeated
the Pennsylvania Military Col
lege frosh, 28-21, Friday, at Homewood.
P.M.C., sporting a strong passing threat and a stout defense,
were "upset" by our hustling and
aggressive frosh squad.
"Our competitive attitude and
hard hitting attack were big factors in the victory," beamed
Coach Bob Scott.
This year's contingent averaged
over thirty points per game, and
was the highest scoring frosh
team that Scott has coached in
13 years. The squad possessed an all-around attack. After
recovering from a midseason low
point against Western Maryland,
the Baby Jays' spirit and enthusiasm proved strong.
Defense Impressive
Led by an improved pass coverage and strong interior line,
the frosh defense turned out to
be a major stumbling block for
the PMC offense. Ends Bob
Billows,
Dick
and
Rohlfing
tackles Neal Vinson and Jim
Lotto, and center Bill Nersesian
consistently applied pressure on
the opponent's quarterback.
Meanwhile the secondary of
Dave Hooper, Ed McGinnis, and
John Hicks adequately covered
opponent's pass receivers. Steve
Clark was aggressive as defensive
tackle. Nevertheless PMC was
able to connect on several passes
to the flat. One of these ended
in a 66 yard run for their first
score.
The Scoring Trio
Russell Moore, Paul Weiss, and
Bob Rohlfing again sparked the
Hopkins offense. Quarterback
Moore was 8 for 18 through the
air, and connected for two touchdowns and one conversion. Weiss
gained 173 yards in 23 attempts
for an average of about eight
yards per carry. He sported two
TD's rushing and one on a pass
from Moore.
Rohlfing scored the fourth Jay
TD on a "freak" pass that
bounced off the intended receiver, Larry Roberts. Rohlfing
also gained two points for the
frosh when he tackled a PMC
halfback in the end zone for a
safety. John Hicks, filling in for
injured Dan Rosenfeld, gave a
fine performance in the fullback
slot, gaining about five yards per
carry.
Weiss came up with the first
score of the contest on a 36 yard
jaunt in the first quarter. PMC
quickly came back with its 66
yard pass play, but they were
later unable to stop the Frosh
Jays' attack. Weiss again scored,
this time on a one yard plunge,
then proceeded to score a twopoint conversion. The second
quarter saw Rohlfing spill PMC
for the safety, and Moore hit
Weiss on a 14 yard TD pass.
Neither team posted a score in
the third period, but in the final
quarter, Hopkins and PMC both
crossed the goal line. With 55
seconds remaining, Penn. Military scored again, and the contest ended 28-21.
Season Statistics
Weiss led the frosh gridmen
in the season's scoring-60 points
in three games. He gained 333

By JEFF LAUREN
Trying to build up a win
streak as long as its early season
losing streak, the varsity soccer
team meets Drexel at 2:30 p.m.
here tomorrow.
The booters will be trying for
their third straight victory. After
losing their first five games, they
finally combined a strong defense, a powerful attack, and the
lucky scoring breaks to upset
Towson 3-2 and Washington
College 4-1 last week.
They played the Towson game

clinch the championship of the

Victory Over Devils
Would Give Gridders
Miracle Worker Tag

By MIKE PHILLIPS
"Victory" and "miracle" will
have the same meaning for the
varsity football team when it
faces Dickinson tomorrow without the services of at least two
starters. The clash is scheduled
for 1:30 P.M. at Homewood Field.
In this last home game of the
Season, the Jays will be minus
quarterback Phil Parthemore and
interior lineman Don Yablonowitz, both of whom will see no
more action for 1966. Senior
'Parthemore, with a displaced
metacarpal bone in his wrist,
ended his Jay grid career on an
untimely note early in the first
quarter of last week's game with
Swarthmore.
Bob Shannon, who did the
team's punting after Parthemore's departure, and Denny
Ferrazzano are also on the doubtful list. Now vying for the quarterback slot are Mike Shaw and
Jim Feely. Shaw handled most of
the team's air traffic (13 of 30
passes for 95 yards) a week ago.
Tom McDonough will take Feely's
split end spot, if he quarterbacks.
